raw_text:
Dutch watch Van Gogh's last film
 
 The last film to be made by the slain Dutch director Theo van Gogh, called 06/05, has been premiered in The Hague.
 
 Members of Van Gogh's family and celebrities attended the screening of 06/05, based on the murder of the anti-immigration politician Pim Fortuyn. Van Gogh was shot and stabbed to death in Amsterdam six weeks ago. A Dutch-Moroccan man suspected of radical Islamist links has been charged. The killing, and Fortuyn's death in 2002, convulsed the Netherlands. Many Dutch people have questioned their country's self-image as a peaceful, tolerant nation in the wake of the murders, which triggered heated debate about immigration.
 
 An animal rights activist was sentenced to 18 years in prison last year for killing Fortuyn. Earlier this year, Van Gogh made a film accusing Islam of promoting violence against women. It caused outrage among Muslims and death threats were made against him. The film 06/05 will become available on the internet on Wednesday and go on general release in Dutch cinemas in January. Van Gogh's movie mixes real images of the day of Fortuyn's murder with a fictional plot about Dutch intelligence services conspiring to silence the politician. The story unfolds through the eyes of a freelance photographer who unwittingly takes pictures revealing the involvement of Dutch authorities in Fortuyn's murder. Photographer Jim de Booy then goes on the run from secret service agents who burgle his home and threaten his family.
llama3.2:1b: The last film made by Theo van Gogh, titled 06/05, has been premiered in The Hague after being completed several months ago. It is based on the murder of anti-immigration politician Pim Fortuyn and features a fictional plot about Dutch intelligence services conspiring to silence him. The film was produced with the involvement of Van Gogh's family and celebrities, and will be available online and in cinemas in January.
llama3.2:3b: Theo van Gogh's film "06/05" premiered in The Hague, based on Pim Fortuyn's murder, and sparked debate about immigration in the Netherlands.
gemma2:2b: "06/05", the last film by Theo van Gogh, premiered in The Hague after his death. It recounts the events surrounding Pim Fortuyn's murder and is based on conspiracy theories about Dutch authorities' involvement.  The film combines real images of Fortuyn's assassination with a fictional narrative and will be available online and in theaters in January.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Dutch director Theo van Gogh released a last-minute film called "06/05" based on the shooting and stabbing of his late wife Pim Fortuyn in Amsterdam six weeks ago. The film, which accuses Islam of promoting violence against women, will go on public release in Dutch cinemas in January. Jim de Booy, the freelance photographer who captured the footage of the murder scene, has now become a fugitive after being arrested and facing charges for conspiracy to silence Fortuyn.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Dutch director Theo van Gogh's last film, 06/05 based on Pim Fortuyn's death, has premiered in The Hague. Van Gogh was shot and stabbed six weeks ago; a radical Islamist suspect is charged. The Netherlands has been deeply affected by the murders of anti-immigration politicians, leading to questioning about its image as peaceful. Van Gogh's film criticizes Islam for violence against women and reveals Dutch involvement in Fortuyn's murder, becoming available online on Wednesday.
qwen2.5:3b: The last film made by slain Dutch director Theo van Gogh, "06/05," based on Pim Fortuyn's murder in 2004, was premiered in The Hague. Van Gogh's life ended six weeks after the incident. A Dutch-Moroccan suspect with radical Islamist links has been charged. The film sparked debate about immigration and national identity post-murder. In 2017, an animal rights activist got 18 years for killing Fortuyn; van Gogh faced threats over a previous anti-Islam film. "06/05" blends real footage with fiction about Dutch intelligence agencies' involvement in the murder, seen through the eyes of a photographer on the run. The film will be available online and released in cinemas starting January 2017.
